Lo Stato di Eccezione/The State of Exception (2008)

 
Judge: 
I will read now and you repeat what I say. Okay?

Witness: 
Yes.

Judge reads the following statement, which the Witness repeats. The sound of the Witness's statement is interspersed with a view of him crying during his subsequent testimony:
Understanding that I am morally and legally responsible for my testimony....
(Consapevole della responsabilità morale e giuridica che assumo)

Prosecutor:
Do you remember that day?

Witness:
The 29th?

Prosecutor:
Yes, the 29th of September [1944].

Witness:
September 29th.

Prosecutor:
Did you see any episodes [of violence]?

Witness:
Ah, not a lot. I saw some dead people, that's all. 

[Camera switches to an aerial map of the region where the massacre occurred 62 years earlier, and other footage from that era.]

Narrator (director German Maccioni):
Between 29 September and 5 October 1944, more than 100 small villages around Marzabotto, Monsuno, and Grizzana were the site of an extermination campaign [carried out by Germany's Waffen SS]: 760 dead in only 7 days. 

Lawyer for the plaintiffs = elderly survivors of the massacre in 1944:
Marzabotto is the archetype of the "state of exception." This idea of the state of exception refers to the elimination of an entire community by a group of criminals. 

Narrator:
An entire farming community was annihilated based on a predetermined plan.

Lawyer addressing his clients, the survivors: 
Your injury is not only a result of the losses you have suffered. You were also injured by the long delay before you were able to seek justice in court. ....

Clip 1:28-33
Lawyer for the defense:
History will also be written based on the transcript of this trial.
